importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the current state of humanitarian conditions in Gaza, indicating that the food supply crisis is ongoing and requires urgent international attention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The food supplies currently available are enough to feed half a million people for two weeks, highlighting the urgency of scaling up aid to prevent widespread famine.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza are still far below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings (Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara) are currently operational, severely limiting aid flow.
The UN World Food Programme (WFP) operates 26 food distribution points in Gaza, up from five, but still far short of the goal of 145.
The US-brokered ceasefire is seen as vital to enabling humanitarian access and preventing famine in northern Gaza.
Humanitarian aid has reached northern Gaza via southern routes, but not in large convoys or to Gaza City and northern areas.
The Rafah crossing remains closed, pending Hamas's return of more Israeli captives' bodies.
Hamas has so far returned 13 of 28 pledged captives' bodies, with two more announced for delivery.
Many Palestinians are rationing food due to fear of supply disruption and uncertainty about the ceasefire’s longevity.
The WFP has not been granted permission to use the Salah al-Din Street, a major north-south route, for aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating food aid to vulnerable populations worldwide.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article as it reports on the current state of food deliveries to Gaza and advocates for more border crossings to be opened to increase humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory under Israeli control, currently experiencing a severe humanitarian crisis due to conflict and blockade.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gaza Strip is the primary location of the food supply crisis, and the article details the scale of the humanitarian emergency and the challenges in delivering aid.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing is one of only two currently open, significantly restricting the volume of food and aid that can enter Gaza.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim in Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Another Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza, currently operational.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing, along with Karem Abu Salem, is one of the only two active routes for humanitarian aid into Gaza, limiting access to northern and central areas.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its closure, pending the return of Israeli captives’ remains, blocks a potential alternative route for humanitarian aid, worsening the food shortage in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south road in Gaza, currently restricted for humanitarian use.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been allowed to use this route, which would have allowed broader distribution of food to northern Gaza, especially to Gaza City.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group that controls Gaza and has been involved in conflict with Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is central to the political dynamics of the ceasefire, as its agreement to return captives’ bodies is a condition for reopening the Rafah crossing and easing humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister, who has stated that the Rafah crossing will remain closed until Hamas returns captives' bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu's position reinforces the political and security barriers to humanitarian access, directly impacting aid delivery timelines and routes.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President, who brokered the ceasefire that enables humanitarian access to Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s role in facilitating the ceasefire is critical, as the article emphasizes that the ceasefire is the only viable path to saving lives and preventing famine.

namedEntities.name: US-brokered ceasefire
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A peace agreement brokered by US President Donald Trump, intended to end hostilities in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ceasefire is described as vital for enabling aid delivery, and its sustainability directly affects the ability to feed the population in Gaza.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically low, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily—far below the 2,000-tonne target—due to just two open border crossings (Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara). Despite increasing to 26 distribution points from five, the WFP still lacks access to key routes like Salah al-Din Street and the Rafah crossing, which remains closed until Hamas returns more captives' bodies. The US-brokered ceasefire is seen as essential for sustained humanitarian access, and while some aid has reached northern Gaza via southern routes, most populations are rationing food due to fear of renewed conflict. The situation underscores the urgent need for more crossings, greater access, and political commitment to humanitarian aid delivery.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
